The '''Financial Stability Board''' ('''FSB''') is an international body that monitors and makes recommendations about the [[global financial system]]. It was established after the [[2009 G20 London summit|G20 London summit]] in April 2009 as a successor to the [[Financial Stability Forum]] (FSF). The Board includes all [[G20 major economies]], FSF members, and the [[European Commission]]. Hosted and funded by the [[Bank for International Settlements]], the board is based in [[Basel, Switzerland|Basel]], [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsb.org/contact/|title=Contact|publisher=}}</ref>
== History == ===Financial Stability Forum === {{Main|Financial Stability Forum}}
The FSB's predecessor organization, the Financial Stability Forum (FSF), had emerged from a group of [[finance ministry|finance ministries]], [[central bank]]ers, and international financial bodies, which had been founded in 1999 to promote international financial stability by the finance ministers and central bank governors of [[G7]] countries.<ref name="Founding">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Genesis of the FSF | url = http://www.fsforum.org/about/genesis_of_the_fsf.html| work = | publisher = Financial Stability Forum| archive-date = 14 June 2008| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080614141837/http://www.fsforum.org/about/genesis_of_the_fsf.html | format = | doi = | accessdate = 30 April 2016 }}</ref> The FSF facilitated discussion and cooperation on supervision and surveillance of financial institutions, transactions, and events. FSF was managed by a small secretariat housed at the [[Bank for International Settlements]] in [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]].<ref name="FSF home">{{cite web | title = Home/News| work = | publisher = Financial Stability Forum| date = | url = http://www.fsforum.org| archive-date = 12 May 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090512222115/http://www.fsforum.org/ | format = | doi = | accessdate = 30 April 2016 }}</ref> The FSF membership included about a dozen nations who participate through their central banks, financial ministries and departments, and securities regulators, including: the [[United States]], [[Japan]], [[Germany]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]], the [[Netherlands]] and several other industrialized economies as well as several international economic organizations.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Who we are | url = http://www.fsforum.org/about/who_we_are.html| work = | publisher = Financial Stability Forum| archive-date = 14 June 2008| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080614141842/http://www.fsforum.org/about/who_we_are.html| format = | doi = | accessdate = 30 April 2016 }}</ref> At the G20 summit on 15 November 2008, it was agreed that the membership of the FSF will be expanded to include emerging economies, such as China. The [[2009 G20 London summit]] decided to establish a successor to the FSF, the Financial Stability Board (FSB) to include members of the G20 who had not been FSF members.<ref>{{cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Financial Stability Forum decides to broaden its membership |work= |publisher=Financial Stability Forum |date=12 March 2009 |url=http://www.fsforum.org/press/pr_090312b.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090411064057/http://www.fsforum.org/press/pr_090312b.pdf |archive-date=11 April 2009 |format= |doi= |accessdate=30 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit }}</ref>
===Founding === The Financial Stability Forum met in [[Rome]] on 28–29 March 2008 in connection with the [[Bank for International Settlements]]. Members discussed current challenges in financial markets, and various policy options to address them from this point forward.<ref name="BIS 0308">{{cite web|url= http://www.bis.org/press/p080329.htm |title=Press release: Financial Stability Forum meets in Rome|publisher=}}</ref> At this meeting, the FSF discussed a report to be delivered to [[G7]] Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors in April 2008. The report identifies key weaknesses underlying current financial turmoil, and recommends actions to improve market and institutional resilience. The FSF discussed work underway at the [[International Monetary Fund]] and [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] with regard to [[sovereign wealth fund]]s. The International Monetary Fund is working closely with sovereign wealth funds to identify a set of voluntary best practice guidelines, and is focusing on the governance, institutional arrangements and transparency of sovereign wealth funds.<ref name="BIS 0308"/> On 12 April 2008, the FSF delivered a report to the G7 Finance Ministers detailing its recommendations:<ref name="FSFReport">{{cite book|title=Report of the Financial Stability Forum on Enhancing Market and Institutional Resilience|date=7 April 2008|publisher=Financial Stability Forum|url=http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/r_0804.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bis.org/press/p080412.htm|title=Press release: Financial Stability Forum Recommends Actions to Enhance Market and Institutional Resilience|publisher=}}</ref> * Strengthen prudential oversight of capital, liquidity, and risk management * Enhance transparency and valuation * Change the role and uses of [[credit rating]]s * Strengthen the authorities' responsiveness to risks * Make robust arrangements for dealing with stress in the financial system
=== 2012 reforms === The High-Level Panel on the Governance of the FSB was an independent initiative coordinated by [[Domenico Lombardi]] of the [[Brookings Institution]] and funded by the [[The Connect U.S. Fund|Connect U.S. Fund]]. It assembled a high-level panel of experts, including [[Uganda]]'s former [[Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development (Uganda)|Finance Minister]] and [[Governor of the Bank of Uganda|Central Bank Governor]] of Uganda [[Ezra Suruma]], former [[Prime Minister of Kyrgyzstan|Prime Minister]] of [[Kyrgyzstan]] [[Djoomart Otorbaev]], former [[Minister of Finance and Public Credit of Colombia|Finance Minister]] of [[Colombia]] [[José Antonio Ocampo]], and [[Jacques Mistral]], a former member of [[France]]'s Council of Economic Analysis.<ref name="newrules">{{cite web|title=What We Do: High-Level Panel on the Governance of the Financial Stability Board|url=http://www.new-rules.org/what-we-do/fsb-unlocking-the-black-box/hlp-on-fsb-governance|website=New Rules for Global Finance|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> Lombardi published the panel's final report in September 2011 as a Brookings Issue Paper, concluding that the FSB's governance had not evolved as quickly as its prominence. It made several recommendations:<ref name="brookings">{{cite book|author1=Domenico Lombardi|authorlink1=Domenico Lombardi|title=The Governance of the Financial Stability Board|date=September 2011|publisher=Brookings Institution|location=Washington, DC|url=https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/FSB_Issues_Paper_Lombardi.pdf|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref>
At the [[2011 G20 Cannes summit]], the G20 called for a strengthening of the FSB's capacity resources and governance by establishing the FSB "on an enduring organizational basis".<ref name="history">{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://www.fsb.org/about/history/|website=Financial Stability Board|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> In its 2012 report to the [[2012 G20 Los Cabos summit|G20 Los Cabos summit]], the FSB set out concrete steps to strengthen the organization's capacity, resources, and governance as well as establish it on an enduring organizational footing. The G20 endorsed the FSB's restated and amended charter.<ref>{{cite book|title=Report to the G20 Los Cabos Summit on Strengthening FSB Capacity, Resources and Governance|date=12 June 2012|publisher=Financial Stability Board|url=http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/r_120619c.pdf|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> In January 2013, the FSB became a separate legal entity in the form of an association or "Verein" under Swiss law, when its Articles of Association were adopted by the FSB Plenary.<ref name="ar4">{{cite book|author1=Financial Stability Board|title=4th Annual Report|date=December 2017|publisher=Financial Stability Board|location=Basel|url=http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/P160118.pdf}}</ref>
The FSB is hosted and funded by the Bank for International Settlements under a five-year agreement executed between the two in January 2013. The bank bears the majority of the FSB's operating expenses, and the FSB does not have any assets, liabilities, or revenue.<ref name="ar4"/>
=== 2016 reforms===
In late July 2016, after the world markets had faced a number of crises, including terrorism and the UK's [[Brexit|decision to leave]] the [[European Union]], Carney sent a letter to Finance Ministers attending the G20 Summit and to Central Bank Governors outlining the reforms the FSB had made<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theasianbanker.com/press-releases/fsb-chair-updates-g20-finance-ministers-and-central-bank-governors-on-progress-in-advancing-the-fsb%E2%80%99s-2016-priorities |title=FSB Chair updates G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors on progress in advancing the FSB’s 2016 priorities |author= |date=24 July 2016 |website=The Asian Banker |access-date=25 July 2016 |quote=The letter outlines the progress the FSB is making in advancing its priorities for 2016}}</ref> indicating that the global economy and financial system had "continued to function effectively" and had "weathered" the "spikes in uncertainty and risk aversion", confirming that "this resilience in the face of stress demonstrates the enduring benefits of G20 post-crisis reforms". He emphasized the value of specific reforms that had been implemented by the Financial Stability Board stating that these had "dampened aftershocks from [global financial crises] rather than amplifying them". He expressed confidence in the FSB's strategies, stating that "resilience in the face of stress demonstrates the enduring benefits of G20 post-crisis reforms".<ref>{{cite news |last=Szu |first=Ping Chan |date=24 July 2016 |title=G20: Chancellor eyes clarity on Brexit deal 'later this year' as vote raises global risks |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/07/24/g20-chancellor-eyes-clarity-on-brexit-deal-later-this-year-as-vo |work=The Telegraph |location=London, UK |access-date=25 July 2016}}</ref>
The FSB published the pre-G20 summit letter<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fsb.org/2016/07/fsb-chair-updates-g20-finance-ministers-and-central-bank-governors-on-progress-in-advancing-the-fsbs-2016-priorities/ |title=FSB Chair updates G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors on progress in advancing the FSB’s 2016 priorities |author=|date=24 July 2016 |website=FSB |publisher=FSB |access-date=25 July 2016}}</ref> in light of the "two spikes in uncertainty and risk aversion" weathered by the global economy and financial system as of late July 2016, which outlined its priorities for 2016: * Promote a coordinated program of reforms to deliver resilient sources of market-based finance, including addressing structural vulnerabilities associated with [[asset management]] * Develop robust financial market infrastructure, including assessing policies on central counterparty resilience, recovery, and resolvability, and recommending any necessary improvements * Support effective [[Macroprudential regulation|macroprudential]] arrangements by drawing lessons from countries that have applied macroprudential policy frameworks and tools, working in partnership with the [[International Monetary Fund]] and [[Bank for International Settlements]]
In addition to the priorities listed above, the FSB also sought to: * Pursue the full and consistent implementation of post-crisis reforms, while addressing material unintended consequences * Address new and emerging vulnerabilities in the financial system, including those associated with conduct, correspondent banking and climate change * Monitor the potentially systemic implications of [[Financial technology|financial technology]] [[Financial innovation|innovations]], and the systemic risks arising from operational disruptions
In November 2016, the FSB and the board of the Bank for International Settlements agreed to a further five-year extension of the agreement from January 2018 to 2023.<ref name="ar4"/>
== Overview == The FSB represented the G20 leaders' first major international institutional innovation. [[U.S. Treasury]] [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Secretary]] [[Tim Geithner]] has described it as "in effect, a fourth pillar" of the architecture of global economic governance. The FSB has been assigned a number of important tasks, working alongside the International Monetary Fund, [[World Bank]], and the [[World Trade Organization]]. Chairman of the board is the Canadian [[Mark Carney]], [[Governor of the Bank of England|Governor]] of the [[Bank of England]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Mark Carney gets chance to reshape Bank of England after departure of deputy governor|url=http://business.financialpost.com/2013/06/14/mark-carney-gets-chance-to-reshape-bank-of-england-as-deputy-governor-departs |accessdate=20 June 2013|work=[[Financial Post]]|date=13 June 2013}}</ref>
Unlike most multilateral financial institutions, the FSB lacks a legal form and any formal power, given that its charter is an informal and nonbinding memorandum of understanding for cooperation adopted by its members.<ref name="brookings"/>
=== Membership === The FSB has 68 member institutions, comprising ministries of finance, central banks, and supervisory and regulatory authorities from 25 jurisdictions as well as 10 international organizations and [[Standards organization|standard-setting bodies]], and 6 Regional Consultative Groups reaching out to 65 other jurisdictions around the world.<ref name="ar4"/><ref name="Members">{{cite web |url=http://www.financialstabilityboard.org/members/links.htm |title=Links to FSB members |publisher=Financial Stability Board |accessdate=17 November 2011}}</ref>
{| | * {{ARG}} * {{AUS}} * {{BRA}} * {{CAN}} * {{CHN}} * {{FRA}} * {{DEU}} * {{HKG}} | * {{IND}} * {{IDN}} * {{ITA}} * {{JPN}} * {{MEX}} * {{NED}} * {{RUS}} * {{SAU}} | * {{SIN}} * {{ZAF}} * {{KOR}} * {{ESP}} * {{CHE}} * {{TUR}} * {{GBR}} * {{USA}} |}
;Organizations: * [[Bank for International Settlements]] * [[European Central Bank]] * [[European Commission]] * [[International Monetary Fund]] * [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] * [[The World Bank]]
;Standard-setting bodies: * [[Basel Committee on Banking Supervision]] * [[International Association of Insurance Supervisors]] * [[International Organization of Securities Commissions]]
=== Chairs ===
As a 2011 [[Brookings Institution]] report noted, there are no set rules for how the FSB chair is selected, reflecting the FSB's newness as well as the "central banking culture of discretion and informality that permeates the institution".<ref name = "brookings"/>
* [[Mario Draghi]] (2009–2011), current [[President of the European Central Bank|President]] of the [[European Central Bank]] and former Governor of the [[Banca d'Italia|Bank of Italy]] * [[Mark Carney]] (2011–present), current [[Governor of the Bank of England|Governor]] of the [[Bank of England]] and former [[Governor of the Bank of Canada|Governor]] of the [[Bank of Canada]]

[[File:Tobacconist's sign, England, 1750-1900 Wellcome L0058305.jpg|thumb|Figure likely meant to portray a [[Powhatan]] leader, made in ~1750 and used to advertise a tobacconist's shop in England until 1900. At the time the sign was made, the Powhatan Confederacy had been destroyed and its people enslaved for decades.]] The '''history of nicotine marketing''' stretches back centuries. [[Nicotine marketing]] has continually developed new techniques in response to historical circumstances, societal and technological change, and regulation. Countermarketing has also changed, in both message and commoness, over the decades, often in response to pro-nicotine marketing.
==Pre-1800==
The coughing, throat irritation, and shortness of breath caused by smoking are obvious, and tobacco was criticized as unhealthy long before the invention of the [[clinical study]]. In the 1604 [[A Counterblaste to Tobacco]], [[James I of England|James VI of Scotland and I of England]] described smoking as "A custome lothsome to the eye, hatefull to the Nose, harmefull to the braine, dangerous to the Lungs, and in the blacke stinking fume thereof, neerest resembling the horrible [[Styx (mythology)|Stigian]] smoke of the pit that is bottomelesse", and urged his subjects not to use tobacco.<ref name=counterblaste>[http://www.laits.utexas.edu/poltheory/james/blaste/ ''A Counterblaste to Tobacco'' (retrieved February 22, 2008)] Quote: A custome lothsome to the eye, hatefull to the Nose, harmefull to the braine, dangerous to the Lungs, and in the blacke stinking fume thereof, neerest resembling the horrible [[Styx (mythology)|Stigian]] smoke of the pit that is bottomelesse.</ref> In the 1600s, many countries banned its use.<ref name="Alston_2002">{{Cite journal| volume = 39| issue = 4| pages = 425–445| last1 = Alston| first1 = Lee J.| last2 = Dupré| first2 = Ruth| last3 = Nonnenmacher| first3 = Tomas| title = Social reformers and regulation: the prohibition of cigarettes in the United States and Canada| journal = Explorations in Economic History| date = 2002|url=https://www.colorado.edu/ibs/es/alston/econ8534/SectionIX/Alston,_Dupre_and_Nonnenmacher,_Social_Reformers_and_Regulation.pdf}}</ref> [[Pope]] [[Urban VIII]] issued a 1624 papal bull condemning tobacco and making its use in holy places punishable by excommunication;<ref>{{cite book| title=Tobacco: A Cultural History of How an Exotic Plant Seduced Civilization| first=Iain| last=Gately| year=2001| publisher=Simon & Schuster| isbn=978-0-8021-3960-3}}</ref> [[Pope Benedict XIII]] repealed the ban one hundred years later.<ref>Cutler, Abigail. "The Ashtray of History", ''The Atlantic Monthly'', January/February 2007.</ref>
==1800–1880==
[[File:Sputt ikkje på golvet.jpg|thumb|upright=0.6|right|A sign asks readers (likely tobacco chewers) not to spit on the floor. Part of an anti-[[tuberculosis]] campaign by the [[Norwegian Women's Public Health Association]].]] The first known nicotine advertisement in the United States was for the snuff and tobacco products and was placed in the New York daily paper in 1789. At the time, American tobacco markets were local. Consumers would generally request tobacco by quality, not brand name, until after the 1840s.<ref name="scriptorke.edu">[http://scriptorium.lib.duke.edu/eaa/tobacco.html More About Tobacco Advertising and the Tobacco Collections]. Scriptorium.lib.duke.edu.</ref>
Many European tobacco bans were repealed during the [[Revolutions of 1848]].
Cigarettes were first made in [[Seville]], from cigar scraps. British soldiers took up the habit during the [[Crimean War]] (1853–1856).<ref name="Alston_2002"/> The [[American Civil War]] in the early 1860s also led to increased demand for tobacco from American soldiers, and in non-tobacco-growing regions.<ref name="Alston_2002"/>
Public health measures against chewing tobacco (spitting, especially other than in a [[spitoon]], spread diseases such as [[influenza|flu]] and [[tuberculosis]]) increased cigarette consumption.<ref name="Alston_2002"/>
After the development of color [[lithography]] in the late 1870s, collectible picture series were printed onto [[cigarette card]]s, previously only used to stiffen the packaging.<ref name="scriptorke.edu"/>
In 1913, a cigarette brand was advertised nationally for the first time in the US. [[RJ Reynolds]] advertised it as milder than competing cigarettes.<ref name=filters_dangerous>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/tc.11.suppl_1.i40 |pmid=11893814 |pmc=1766061 |title=Cigarette filter ventilation is a defective design because of misleading taste, bigger puffs, and blocked vents |journal=Tobacco Control |volume=11 |pages=I40–50 |year=2002 |last1=Kozlowski |first1=L T |last2=O'Connor |first2=R J }}</ref>
==Mass production and temperance, 1880–1914==
[[File:Bonsack machine.png|thumb|left|An early [[James Albert Bonsack|cigarette-rolling machine]] mass-produced cigarettes at fifty times the speed of a human cigarette roller.]] Pre-rolled cigarettes, like cigars, were initially expensive, as a skilled cigarette roller could produce only about four cigarettes per minute on average<ref name="output">[http://www.wclynx.com/burntofferings/adscigmaker.html Bonsack's cigarette machine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061113183233/http://www.wclynx.com/burntofferings/adscigmaker.html |date=2006-11-13 }}. URL last accessed 2006-10-11.</ref> Cigarette-making machines were developed in the 1880s, replacing hand-rolling.<ref name=time_advertising>{{cite news|last=James |first=Randy |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1905530,00.html |title=A Brief History Of Cigarette Advertising |publisher=TIME |date=2009-06-15 |accessdate=2012-03-25}}</ref> One early machine could roll 120,000 cigarettes in 10 hours, or 200 a minute.<ref name="output"/><ref name="pat1">[http://patimg1.uspto.gov/.piw?Docid=0238640&idkey=NONE U.S. patent 238,640], with diagrams. URL last accessed 2006-10-11.</ref><ref name="pat2">[http://patimg2.uspto.gov/.piw?Docid=00247795&idkey=NONE U.S. patent 247,795], with diagrams. URL last accessed 2006-10-11</ref> Mass production revolutionized the [[tobacco industry|cigarette industry]].<ref name="bennett">Bennett, W.: ''[http://tobaccodocuments.org/nysa_ti_m2/TI08961040.html The Cigarette Century]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}'', ''[[Science (magazine)|Science]] '''80''''', September/October 1980. URL last accessed 2006-10-11.</ref> Cigarette companies began to reckon production in millions of cigarettes per day.<ref name="scriptorke.edu"/>
Higher production and cheaper cigarettes gave companies an incentive to increase consumption. By the last quarter of the 19th century, magazines carried advertisements for different brands of cigarettes, snuff, and pipe tobacco.<ref name=time_advertising/> Demand for cigarettes rose exponentially, ~doubling every five years in Canada and the US (until demand began to rise even faster, ~tripling during the four years of [[World War I]]).<ref name="Alston_2002"/>{{rp|429, Fig.1}}
===Anti-tobacco movements=== {{main|Tobacco control}}
[[File:Smoking Dangers - 1905 new.png|thumb|right|"The Deadly Cigarette"; a 1905 cartoon celebrates bans on the sale and possession of tobacco in three U.S. States, and calls on other states follow their lead.]] In the late 1800s, the [[temperance movement]] was strongly involved in anti-tobacco compaigns, and particularly with the prevention of youth smoking. They argued that smoking was addictive, unhealthy, stunted the growth of children, and, in women, was harmful during pregnancy.<ref name=australian_temperance>{{Cite web| title = The anti-tobacco reform and the temperance movement in Australia: connections and differences. - Free Online Library| accessdate = 2018-05-19| url = https://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+anti-tobacco+reform+and+the+temperance+movement+in+Australia%3a...-a021231027}}</ref>
By 1890, 26 American states had banned sales to minors. Over the next decade, further restrictions were legislated, including prohibitions on sale; measures were widely circumvented, for instance by selling expensive matches and giving away cigarettes with them, so there were further bans on giving out free samples of cigarettes.<ref name="Alston_2002"/>
After women won the vote in the early 1900s, temperance groups successfully campaigned for [[Juvenile Smoking Law]]s throughout Australia. At this time, most adults there smoked pipes, and cigarettes were used only by juveniles.<ref name=australian_temperance/>
== 1914–1950 == [[File:Nurse lights patients pipe.jpg|thumb|left|A poster soliciting donations for a fund to send cigarettes to the front in WWI. A nurse lights a pipe for an injured soldier, who guides her hand. The implication that tobacco heals is subtle, but was consistently used.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tobacco.stanford.edu/tobacco_main/images.php?token2=fm_st232.php&token1=fm_img6772.php&theme_file=fm_mt001.php&theme_name=Doctors+Smoking&subtheme_name=Hospitalized+Patients|title=Stanford Research into the Impact of Tobacco Advertising|website=tobacco.stanford.edu}}</ref> There is also an implication that the nurse finds smoking sexually attractive.]]
=== World War I === [[File:Down with Germany - Welcome to the Boys.jpg|thumb|World War I, circa 1915. A tobacco concession stand, with ads, at [[CFB Valcartier|Valcartier military base]] near [[Quebec City]]]]
Free or subsidized branded cigarettes were distributed to troops during [[World War I]].<ref name=time_advertising/> Demand for cigarettes in North America, which had been ~doubling every five years, began to rise even faster, ~tripling during the four years of war.<ref name="Alston_2002"/>{{rp|429, Fig.1}}
In the face of imminent violent death, the health harms of cigarettes became less of a concern, and there was public support for drives to get cigarettes to the front lines.<ref name=australian_temperance/> Billions of cigarettes were distributed to soldiers in Europe by national governments, the [[YMCA]], the [[Salvation Army]], and the [[Red Cross]]. Private individuals also donated money to send cigarettes to the front, even from jurisdictions where the sale of cigarettes was illegal. Not giving soldiers cigarettes was seen as unpatriotic.<ref name="Alston_2002"/>
=== Interwar === By the time the war was over, a generation had grown up, and a large proportion of adults smoked, making anti-smoking campaigns substantially more difficult.<ref name=australian_temperance/> Returning soldiers continued to smoke, making smoking more socially acceptable. Temperance groups began to concentrate their efforts on alcohol.<ref name=australian_temperance/> By 1927, American states had repealed all their anti-smoking laws, except those on minors.<ref name="Alston_2002"/>
Modern advertising was created with the innovative techniques used in tobacco advertising beginning in the 1920s.<ref name="Gifford2010p15">Donald G. Gifford (2010) [https://books.google.com/books?id=6UYzFt5Qgk4C&pg=PA15 ''Suing the Tobacco and Lead Pigment Industries''], p.15 quotation: {{quotation|...during the early twentieth century, tobacco manufacturers virtually created the modern advertising and marketing industry as it is known today.}}</ref><ref name="GlantzModernAds">Stanton Glantz in ''[[Mad Men]] Season 3 Extra – Clearing the Air – The History of Cigarette Advertising'', part 1, min 3:38 quotation: {{quotation|...development of modern advertising. And it was really the tobacco industry, from the beginning, that was at the forefront of the development of modern, innovative, advertising techniques.}}</ref>
Advertising in the interwar period consisted primarily of full page, color magazine and newspaper advertisements. Many companies created slogans for their brand and used [[celebrity endorsements]] from famous men and women. Some advertisements contained fictional doctors reassuring customers that their specific brand was good for health.<ref name=NYT_deadly>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/20/health/20essay.html | work=The New York Times | first1=Howard | last1=Markel | title=Tracing the Cigarette's Path From Sexy to Deadly | date=2007-03-20}}</ref>
Smoking was also widely seen in [[films]], possibly due to paid [[product placement]].{{see below|Films}}
In 1924, menthol cigarettes were invented,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://patentimages.storage.googleapis.com/pages/US1555580.png|title=Process of Treating Cigarette Tobacco|publisher=United States Patent Office}}</ref> but they were not initially popular, remaining at a few percent of market share until marketing in the fifties.<ref name=FDA_review/>{{rp|35–37}}
In the 1920s, tobacco companies continued to target women, aiming to increase the number of smokers.<ref name="tobaccofreekids1">[http://www.tobaccofreekids.org/Script/DisplayPressRelease.php3?Display=348 Statement: Surgeon General's Report on Women and Tobacco Underscores Need for Congress to Grant FDA Authority Over Tobacco (Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids)]. Tobaccofreekids.org.</ref> At first, in light of the threat of tobacco prohibition from temperance unions, marketing was subtle; it indirectly and deniably suggested that women smoked. Testimonials from smoking female celebrities were used. Ads were designed to "prey on female insecurities about weight and diet", encouraging smoking as a healthy alternative to eating sweets.<ref name=women_mass>{{Cite web| title = Targeting women: Mass marketing begins, Stanford Research into the Impact of Tobacco Advertising| accessdate = 2018-05-19| url = http://tobacco.stanford.edu/tobacco_main/images.php?token2=fm_st024.php&token1=fm_img0516.php&theme_file=fm_mt012.php&theme_name=Targeting%20Women&subtheme_name=Mass%20Marketing%20Begins |quote=As the threat of tobacco prohibition from temperance unions settled down in the late 1920s, tobacco companies became bolder with their approach to targeting women through advertisements, openly targeting women in an attempt to broaden their market and increase sales. The late 1920s saw the beginnings of major mass marketing campaigns designed specifically to target women. Cigarette manufacturers have for a long time subtly suggested in some of their advertising that women smoked, a New York Times article from 1927 reveals. But Chesterfield s 1927 Blow some my way campaign was transparent to the public even at the time of printing, and soon after, the campaigns became less and less subtle. In 1928, Lucky Strike introduced its Cream of the Crop campaign, featuring celebrity testimonials from female smokers, and then followed with Reach for a Lucky Instead of a Sweet in 1929, designed to prey on female insecurities about weight and diet. As the decade turned, many cigarette brands came out of the woodwork and joined in on unabashedly targeting women by illustrating women smoking, rather than hinting at it.}}</ref>
Campaigns used the traditional association that smoking was improper for women to advantage. They marketed cigarettes as "[[Torches of Freedom]]", and made a dependence-inducing drug a symbol of women's independence. Lung cancer rates in women rose sharply.<ref name=lets_smoke_girls>{{Cite web| title = Targeting women:Let's Smoke Girls, Stanford Research into the Impact of Tobacco Advertising| accessdate = 2018-05-19| url = http://tobacco.stanford.edu/tobacco_main/images.php?token2=fm_st025.php&token1=fm_img0541.php&theme_file=fm_mt012.php&theme_name=Targeting%20Women&subtheme_name=Let%27s%20Smoke%20Girls |quote=Before the First World War, smoking was associated with the loose morals of prostitutes and wayward women. Clever marketers managed to turn this around in the 1920s and 1930s, latching onto women s liberation movements and transforming cigarettes into symbols of women's independence. In 1929, as part of this effort, the American Tobacco Company organized marches of women carrying Torches of Freedom (i.e., cigarettes) down New York s 5th Avenue to emphasize their emancipation. The tobacco industry also sponsored training sessions to teach women how to smoke, and competitions for most delicate smoker. Many of the advertisements targeting women throughout the decades have concentrated on women s empowerment. Early examples include I wish I were a man so I could smoke (Velvet, 1912), while later examples like You ve come a long way baby (Virginia Slims) were more clearly exploitive of the Women s Liberation Movement. It is interesting to note that the Marlboro brand, famous for its macho Marlboro Man, was for decades a woman s cigarette (Mild as May with Ivory tips to protect the lips) before it underwent an abrupt sex change in 1954. Only 5 percent of American women smoked in 1923 versus 12 percent in 1932 and 33 percent in 1965 (the peak year). Lung cancer was still a rare disease for women in the 1950s, though by the year 2000 it was killing nearly 70,000 women per year. Cancer of the lung surpassed breast cancer as the leading cause of cancer death among women in 1987.}}</ref>
In 1929 [[Edward Bernays]], commissioned by the [[American Tobacco Company]] to get more women smoking, decided to hire women to smoke their "torches of freedom" as they walked in the [[Easter Sunday Parade]] in New York. He was very careful when picking women to march because "while they should be good looking, they should not look too model-y" and he hired his own photographers to make sure that good pictures were taken and then published around the world.<ref name=Brandt2007-84-85>Brandt, Allan M. (2007). ''The Cigarette Century''. New York: Basic Books, pp. 84-85.</ref>
In 1929, the [[Sturmabteilung]], the paramilitary wing of the [[Nazi Party]], founded a cigarette company as a way to raise funds and make itself less financially dependent on the party leadership. SA members were expected to smoke only [[Sturm-Zigaretten|SA brands]].<ref name="Proctor">Robert N. Proctor, ''The Nazi War on Cancer'', pp. 234–237.</ref> There is evidence that coercion was used to promote the sale of these cigarettes. Through this scheme, a typical SA unit earned hundreds of [[Reichsmarks]] each month.<ref name="Grant">Thomas D. Grant, ''Stormtroopers and Crisis in the Nazi Movement'', p. 102.</ref> The brand also promoted political ideas, with sets of [[cigarette cards]] showing historical army uniforms.<ref>Joyce Goodman and Jane Martin, ''Gender, Colonialism and Education'', p. 81.</ref>
=== Medical concerns === {{quotebox|align=left|width=35%|title=Old joke|quote =Of course it is perfectly easy to give up smoking. One would not like to think that one has become such a slave to tobacco that one cannot do without it—a drug which weakens the heart, damages the nerves, gives you cancer and [[catarrh]] and so on. Personally I have given up smoking repeatedly. |source ={{cite news|title=On Giving Up Smoking |date=1934-11-07 |work= [[Punch (magazine)|Punch]] or The London Charivari|location=London |page= 506}}; this was an old joke even in 1934<ref>{{cite web|url=https://quoteinvestigator.com/2012/09/19/easy-quit-smoking/|title=It's Easy to Quit Smoking. I've Done It a Thousand Times – Quote Investigator|website=quoteinvestigator.com}}</ref>}}
Skyrocketing European lung cancer rates drew attention from doctors in the twenties and thirties.<ref name=1932_habit>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1360-0443.1932.tb04849.x |oclc=79886767 |title=The Cigarette Habit |journal=Addiction |volume=30 |issue=1 |pages=1–27 |year=1932 |last1=Rolleston |first1=J. D }}</ref> Lung cancer had been a vanishingly rare disease. Before 1900, there were only 140 documented cases worldwide.<ref name=nazi_policy/> Then, suddenly, lung cancer became a leading cause of death in many countries (a status it retains to this day).<ref name=nazi_policy/><ref name=media_role/>{{rp|4}}{{better citation needed|date=May 2018}}
Initially, suspicion was cast on causes including road tar, car exhaust, the [[1918 flu pandemic]], racial mixing, and the use of [[chemical weapons in World War I]]. However, in 1929, a statistical analysis strongly linking lung cancer to smoking was published by [[Fritz Lickint]] of [[Dresden]]. He did a [[retrospective cohort study]] showing that those with lung cancer were, disproportionately, smokers. He also found that men got lung cancer at several times the rate of women, and that, in countries where more women smoked, the difference was much smaller.<ref name=nazi_policy/> In 1932, a study in [[Poland]] came to the same conclusion, pointing out that the geographic and gender patterns of Polish lung cancer deaths matched those of smoking, but no other suggested cause, such as industry or cars (rare in Poland at the time).<ref name=nazi_policy/>
The medical community was criticized for [[health effects of tobacco#history|its slow response]] to these findings. One 1932 paper attributed the slow response to smoking being common among doctors, as well as the general population.<ref name=1932_habit/> Some temperance activists had continued to attack tobacco as expensive, addictive, and leading to petty theft. In the thirties, they also began to publicize the medical findings.<ref name=australian_temperance/> There was popular awareness these dangers of smoking (see accompanying quote).
=== World War II === [[File:WWII send your children cigarettes.jpg|thumb|alt=A woman sitting at a desk smoking writes a letter; beside her, a small boy pastes a war stamp into a booklet. Inset, a black-and-white image of a grinning young man in uniform sitting on a bed in a tent smoking and reading a letter; next to him, an opened paper-wrapped package that apparently just contained a carton of cigarettes and the letter. Inset upon the inset, a picture of an open cigarette pack. In the bottom right corner, an icon-like ad saying "BUY WAR BONDS STAMPS" on a red-white-and-blue shield. Text (shortened to avoid repeating the "favorite in the service" claim thrice)''"Today we bought a War Stamp for Bobby -- and <u>Camels</u> for <u>you</u>!"'' Next to those precious letters you write that tell them how you are and what you're doing... the thing men in the service want most from home is ''cigarettes''. When you send cigarettes, remember, the favorite brand in ''all'' the services -- with men in the Army, the Navy, the Marines, the Coast Guard -- is ''Camel''. ...elipsis in transcription...WHEN "MAIL CALL" brings a carton of 'Camels -- it's always good news from home!...elipsis in transcription...(There are 200 cigarettes in a carton of Camels... and with every one he lights, he'll be thinking of you... glad you thought of ''him'')...elipsis in transcription...Send him his favorite... Camels|This WWII ad shows a wife sending her soldier husband a carton of cigarettes, and urges others to do the same. A mention of [[War savings stamps of the United States|War Stamp]]s associates the brand still more closely to war patriotism.]] {{See also|Smoking in the United States military}}
Despite these findings, free and subsidized branded cigarettes were distributed to soldiers (on both sides) during [[World War II]].<ref name=time_advertising/><ref name=not_simple>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.puhe.2007.08.005| issn = 0033-3506| volume = 122| issue = 5| pages = 497–505| last1 = Bachinger| first1 = Eleonore| last2 = McKee| first2 = Martin| last3 = Gilmore| first3 = Anna| title = Tobacco policies in Nazi Germany: not as simple as it seems| journal = Public Health| date = 2008-05| pmid = 18222506| pmc = 2441844}}</ref>
Cigarettes were included in American soldiers' [[C-rations]], since many tobacco companies sent the soldiers cigarettes for free. Cigarette sales reached an all-time high at this point, as cigarette companies were not only able to get soldiers addicted, but specific brands also found a new loyal group of customers as soldiers who smoked their cigarettes returned from the war.<ref name=Randall_history>{{cite web|author=Vernellia R. Randall |url=http://academic.udayton.edu/health/syllabi/tobacco/history.htm |title=The History of Tobacco |publisher=Academic.udayton.edu |date=1999-08-31 |accessdate=2012-03-25}}</ref>
A faction of the [[Nazi Party]] [[Anti-tobacco movement in Nazi Germany|opposed tobacco use]].<ref name=not_simple/> The ''Institute for Tobacco Hazards Research'' was founded. Some of those working with it were involved in mass murder and unethical medical experiments, and killed themselves at the end of the war, including [[Karl Astel]], the head of the institute. The institute and other organizations directed anti-smoking campaigns at both the general public and doctors. Campaigns included pamphlets, [[reprint]]s of academic articles and books, and smoking bans in many public places;<ref name=nazi_policy/> bans were, however, widely ignored.<ref name=not_simple/> An industry-funded counter-institute, the ''Tabacologia medicinalis'', was shut down by [[Leonardo Conti]].<ref name=nazi_policy>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1093/ije/30.1.31| volume = 30| issue = 1| pages = 31–34| last = Proctor| first = Robert N.| title = Commentary: Schairer and Schöniger's forgotten tobacco epidemiology and the Nazi quest for racial purity| journal = International Journal of Epidemiology| accessdate = 2018-05-19| date = 2001-02-01| url = https://academic.oup.com/ije/article/30/1/31/619023}}</ref>
Tobacco companies continue to exploit associations with Nazis to fight anti-tobacco measures. Modern Germany has some of Europe's least restrictive tobacco control policies,<ref name=nazi_policy/> and more Germans both smoke and die of it in consequence.<ref name=red_report>{{Cite conference| publisher = Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum| title = Zigarettenwerbung in Deutschland – Marketing für ein gesundheitsgefährdendes Produkt| location = Heidelberg| series = Rote Reihe: Tabakprävention und Tabakkontrolle| accessdate = 2016-05-01| date = 2012| url = http://www.dkfz.de/de/tabakkontrolle/download/Publikationen/RoteReihe/Band_18_Zigarettenwerbung_in_Deutschland.pdf}}</ref><ref name=factsheet_adban>{{Cite conference| publisher = Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum| last1 = Dr. Annette Bornhäuser| last2 = Dr. med. Martina Pötschke-Langer| title = Factsheet Tabakwerbeverbot| accessdate = 2016-05-01| date = 2001| url = http://www.dkfz.de/de/tabakkontrolle/download/Publikationen/Fakten/Factsheet_Tabakwerbeverbot.pdf}}</ref>
== 1950–70 == Until the 1970s, most tobacco advertising was legal in the United States and most European nations. In the 1940s and 50s, tobacco was a major radio sponsor; in the 1950s and 60s, they became predominantly involved in television.<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|100}} In the United States, in the 1950s and 1960s, cigarette brands frequently sponsored television shows—notably ''[[To Tell the Truth]]'' and ''[[I've Got a Secret]]''. Brand jingles were commonly used on radio and television. Major cigarette companies would advertise their brands in popular TV shows such as ''[[The Flintstones]]'' and ''[[The Beverly Hillbillies]]'', which were watched by many children and teens.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/tc.3.2.134 |jstor=20207023 |pmc=1759332 |title=Promises, promises: Self-regulation of US cigarette broadcast advertising in the 1960s |journal=Tobacco Control |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=134–44 |year=1994 |last1=Pollay |first1=Richard W }}</ref> In 1964, after facing much pressure from the public, The Cigarette Advertising Code was created by the tobacco companies, which prohibited advertising directed to youth.<ref name="John W. Richards 1996 pp. 297" />
Advertising continued to use celebrities and famous athletes. Popular comedian [[Bob Hope]] was used to advertise for cigarette companies.<ref name="John W. Richards 1996 pp. 297" /> The African-American magazine [[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]] often used athletes to advertise major cigarette brands.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/00913367.1992.10673359 |jstor=4188824 |title=Separate, but Not Equal: Racial Segmentation in Cigarette Advertising |journal=Journal of Advertising |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=45–57 |year=1992 |last1=Pollay |first1=Richard W |last2=Lee |first2=Jung S |last3=Carter-Whitney |first3=David }}</ref>
The nicotine industry also promoted [[Nicotine_marketing#"Modified_risk"_products|"modified risk" nicotine products]], falsely [[Implicature|implied]] to be less harmful, such as roasted, "[[filter cigarette|filter]]", [[menthol cigarette|menthol]], and [[Ventilated cigarettes|ventilated ("light")]] cigarettes.<ref name=levels>{{cite journal | vauthors = Mallock N, Böss L, Burk R, Danziger M, Welsch T, Hahn H, Trieu HL, Hahn J, Pieper E, Henkler-Stephani F, Hutzler C, Luch A | title = Levels of selected analytes in the emissions of "heat not burn" tobacco products that are relevant to assess human health risks | journal = Archives of Toxicology | volume = 92 | issue = 6 | pages = 2145–2149 | date = June 2018 | pmid = 29730817 | pmc = 6002459 | doi = 10.1007/s00204-018-2215-y }}</ref><ref name=lower_toxin>{{cite journal | vauthors = El-Toukhy S, Baig SA, Jeong M, Byron MJ, Ribisl KM, Brewer NT | title = Impact of modified risk tobacco product claims on beliefs of US adults and adolescents | journal = Tobacco Control | volume = 27 | issue = Suppl 1 | pages = tobaccocontrol–2018–054315 | date = August 2018 | pmid = 30158212 | pmc = 6202195 | doi = 10.1136/tobaccocontrol-2018-054315 }}</ref> These products were used to discourage quitting, by offering unwilling smokers an alternative to quitting, and implying that using the alternate product would reduce the hazards of smoking.<ref name=FDA_review/>{{rp|62–65}}<ref name=media_role/> "Modified risk" products also attract new smokers.<ref name=levels/>
It is now known that these products are not less harmful. Filter cigarettes became near-universal, but smokers suffered just as much illness and death.<ref name=filterprob>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1136/tc.2010.040113| eissn = 1468-3318| issn = 0964-4563| volume = 20| issue = Suppl 1| pages = –10–i16| last = Harris| first = Bradford| title = The intractable cigarette 'filter problem'| journal = Tobacco Control| accessdate = 2018-09-04| date = 2011-05-01| url = https://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/20/Suppl_1/i10| pmid = 21504917| pmc = 3088411}}</ref> Initially, efforts were made to develop filters that actually reduced harms; as it became obvious that this was not economically possible, filters were instead designed to turn brown with use.<ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Kennedy| first = Pagan | name-list-format = vanc | title = Who Made That Cigarette Filter?| work = The New York Times| access-date = 2018-09-04| date = 2012-07-06| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/08/magazine/who-made-that-cigarette-filter.html}}</ref><ref name=filter_prob>{{cite journal | vauthors = Harris B | title = The intractable cigarette 'filter problem' | journal = Tobacco Control | volume = 20 Suppl 1 | pages = i10–6 | date = May 2011 | pmid = 21504917 | pmc = 3088411 | doi = 10.1136/tc.2010.040113 }}</ref> Light cigarettes became so popular that, as of 2004, half of American smokers preferred them over regular cigarettes,<ref name=Lavelle_2004>[http://www.abc.net.au/health/thepulse/s1224919.htm Light but just as deadly], by Peter Lavelle. ''The Pulse,'' 21 October 2004.</ref> According to The Federal Government's National Cancer Institute (NCI), light cigarettes provide no benefit to smokers' health.<ref name=NCI_light>[http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Tobacco/light-cigarettes The Truth About "Light" Cigarettes: Questions and Answers], from the [[National Cancer Institute]] factsheet</ref><ref name=NewSci_myth>[https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg18124301.300-safer-cigarette-myth-goes-up-in-smoke.html 'Safer' cigarette myth goes up in smoke], by Andy Coghlan. New Scientist, 2004</ref> There is no evidence that menthol cigarettes are healthier, but there is evidence that they are somewhat easier to become addicted to and harder to quit.<ref name=FDA_review/>{{rp|25–27}}
Racial marketing strategies changed during the fifties, with more attention paid to racial [[market segmentation]]. The [[civil rights movement]] lead to the rise of African-American publications, such as ''[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]''. This helped tobacco companies to target separate marketing messages by race.<ref name=media_role>{{Cite conference| publisher = U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, National Institutes of Health, National Cancer Institute| pages = 684| last1 = Davis| first1 = Ronald M.| last2 = Gilpin| first2 = Elizabeth A.| last3 = Loken| first3 = Barbara| last4 = Viswanath| first4 = K.| last5 = Wakefield| first5 = Melanie A.| title = The role of the media in promoting and reducing tobacco use| series = National Cancer Institute tobacco control monograph series| date = 2008 |url=https://permanent.access.gpo.gov/lps119239/m19_complete.pdf}}</ref>{{rp|57}} Tobacco companies supported civil rights organizations, and advertised their support heavily. Industry motives were, according to their public statements, to support civil rights causes; according to an independent review of internal tobacco industry documents, they were "to increase African American tobacco use, to use African Americans as a frontline force to defend industry policy positions, and to defuse tobacco control efforts". There had been internal resistance to tobacco sponsorship, and some organizations are now rejecting nicotine funding as a matter of policy.<ref name=leadership_sponsorship>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/tc.11.4.336 |pmid=12432159 |pmc=1747674 |title=African American leadership groups: Smoking with the enemy |journal=Tobacco Control |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=336–45 |year=2002 |last1=Yerger |first1=V B |last2=Malone |first2=R. E }}</ref>
Race-specific advertising [[positive feedback|exacerbated]] small (a few percent) racial differences in menthol cigarette product preferences into large (tens of percent) ones.<ref>{{Cite web| last1 = January 5| first1 = Jim Edwards MoneyWatch| last2 = 2011| last3 = Pm| first3 = 3:11| title = Why Big Tobacco Targeted Blacks With Ads for Menthol Cigarettes| accessdate = 2018-05-24| url = https://www.cbsnews.com/news/why-big-tobacco-targeted-blacks-with-ads-for-menthol-cigarettes/}}</ref> Menthol cigarettes are somewhat more addictive,<ref name=FDA_review>{{Cite conference| publisher = US Food and Drug Administration| pages = 252| last = Tobacco Products Scientific Advisory Committee (TPSAC) of the Center for Tobacco Products of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA)| title = Menthol Cigarettes and Public Health: Review of the Scientific Evidence and Recommendations| accessdate = 2018-05-24| date = 2011-07-21| url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170517052326if_/https://www.fda.gov/downloads/AdvisoryCommittees/CommitteesMeetingMaterials/TobaccoProductsScientificAdvisoryCommittee/UCM269697.pdf}}</ref> and it has been argued that race-specific marketing for a more addictive product is a social injustice.<ref name="auto">{{Cite news| last = Tavernise| first = Sabrina| title = Black Health Experts Renew Fight Against Menthol Cigarettes| work = The New York Times| accessdate = 2018-05-24| date = 2016-09-13| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/14/health/menthol-cigarettes-fda.html}}</ref><ref>https://blackdoctor.org/507006/african-american-tobacco-control-leadership-council-to-president-obama-give-our-community-a-fighting-chance/{{full citation needed|date=June 2018}}</ref>
Despite it being illegal at the time, tobacco marketers gave out free cigarette samples to children in black neighbourhoods in the U.S.<ref>{{Cite news| last = Press| first = The Associated| title = Cigarette Suit Says Maker Gave Samples To Children| work = The New York Times| accessdate = 2018-05-24| date = 2004-06-27| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/27/us/cigarette-suit-says-maker-gave-samples-to-children.html}}</ref> Similar practices continue in parts of the world; a 2016 study found over 12% of South African students had been given free cigarettes by tobacco company representative, with lower rates in five other subsaharan countries.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.ypmed.2016.01.018| volume = 91S| pages = S23–S27| last1 = Chandora| first1 = Rachna| last2 = Song| first2 = Yang| last3 = Chaussard| first3 = Martine| last4 = Palipudi| first4 = Krishna Mohan| last5 = Lee| first5 = Kyung Ah| last6 = Ramanandraibe| first6 = Nivo| last7 = Asma| first7 = Samira| last8 = GYTS collaborative group| title = Youth access to cigarettes in six sub-Saharan African countries| journal = Preventive Medicine| date = October 2016| pmid = 26845374}}</ref> Worldwide, 1 in 10 children had been offered free cigarettes by a tobacco company representative, according to a 2000-2007 survey.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=18219269 |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/ss5701a1.htm |year=2008 |author1=Warren |first1=C. W |title=Global youth tobacco surveillance, 2000-2007 |journal=Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report |volume=57 |issue=1 |pages=1–28 |last2=Jones |first2=N. R |last3=Peruga |first3=A |last4=Chauvin |first4=J |last5=Baptiste |first5=J. P |last6=Costa De Silva |first6=V |last7=El Awa |first7=F |last8=Tsouros |first8=A |last9=Rahman |first9=K |last10=Fishburn |first10=B |last11=Bettcher |first11=D. W |last12=Asma |first12=S |author13=Centers for Disease Control Prevention (CDC) }}</ref>
Tobacco companies supported civil rights organizations, and advertised their support heavily. They also hired key figures in the civil rights movement. Industry motives were, according to their public statements, to support civil rights causes; according to an independent review of internal tobacco industry documents, they were "to increase African American tobacco use, to use African Americans as a frontline force to defend industry policy positions, and to defuse tobacco control efforts". Defenses of the industry mounted with the help of vulnerable groups include "our critics are elitist and racist". Some organizations are now rejecting nicotine funding as a matter of policy.<ref name=leadership_sponsorship/>
[[File:A Frank Statement.png|thumb|''A Frank Statement to Cigarette Smokers'' ([[:Wikisource:A Frank Statement|fulltext on Wikisource]]) denied health effects]] In 1954, tobacco companies ran the ad "[[A Frank Statement]]." The ad was the first in a [[disinformation]] campaign, disputing reports that smoking cigarettes could cause lung cancer and had other dangerous health effects.<ref name=frank_statement>[http://www.tobacco.org/Documents/dd/ddfrankstatement.html Daily Doc: TI, Jan 4, 1954: The 'Frank Statement' of 1954]. Tobacco.org. 30 September 2000. Retrieved 17 July 2009.</ref> It also referred to "research of recent years",<ref name=frank_statement/> although solid statistical evidence of a link between smoking and lung cancer had first been published 25 years earlier.<ref name=nazi_policy/>
Prior to 1964, many of the cigarette companies advertised their brand by claiming that their product did not have serious health risks. A couple of examples would be "Play safe with Philip Morris" and "More doctors smoke Camels". Such claims were made both to increase the sales of their product and to combat the increasing public knowledge of smoking's negative health effects.<ref name="John W. Richards 1996 pp. 297">John W. Richards, Jr., Joe B. Tye and Paul M. Fischer, "The Tobacco Industry's Code of Advertising in the United States: Myth and Reality", ''Tobacco Control'', Vol. 5, (Winter 1996), pp. 297</ref> A 1953 industry document claims that the survey brand preference among doctors was done on doctors entering a conference, and asked (among a great many camouflage questions) what brand they had on them; marketers had previously placed packs of their Camels in doctors' hotel rooms before the doctors arrived,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tobacco.stanford.edu/tobacco_main/images_body.php?token1=fm_img18905.php|title=Untitled Document|website=tobacco.stanford.edu}}</ref> which probably biassed the results.
In 1964, ''[[Smoking and Health: Report of the Advisory Committee to the Surgeon General of the United States]]'' was published. It was based on over 7,000 scientific articles that linked tobacco use with cancer and other diseases. This report led to laws requiring warning labels on tobacco products and to restrictions on tobacco advertisements. As these began to come into force, tobacco marketing became more subtle (for instance, the [[Joe Camel]] campaign resulted in increased awareness and uptake of smoking among children).<ref name=While_1995>{{cite journal |vauthors=While D, Kelly S, Huang W, Charlton A |title=Cigarette advertising and onset of smoking in children: questionnaire survey |journal=BMJ |volume=313 |issue=7054 |pages=398–9 |date=17 August 1996|pmid=8761227 |pmc=2351819 |doi=10.1136/bmj.313.7054.398}}</ref> However, restrictions did have an effect on adult quit rates, with its use declining to the point that by 2004, nearly half of all Americans who had ever smoked had quit.<ref name=CDC_decline_2005>{{cite journal |title=Cigarette smoking among adults—United States, 2004 |journal=MMWR Morb. Mortal. Wkly. Rep. |volume=54 |issue=44 |pages=1121–4 |date=November 2005 |pmid=16280969 |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5444a2.htm |author1= Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)}}</ref>
== Post-advertising-restrictions; 1970 and later == {{see also|Regulation of nicotine marketing|Regulation of electronic cigarettes}} [[File:Child wearing Marlboro shirt at Boston City Hall in 1980s (9504744104) 2.jpg|thumb|left|A girl wearing a [[Marlboro (cigarette)|Marlboro]] shirt in the 1980s. Owning and being willing to use promotional items is a significant risk factor for nicotine addiction.<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|258, 240–268}}<ref name=ad_suscept>{{cite journal |doi=10.2105/AJPH.2005.070359 |pmid=17600271 |pmc=1931446 |title=Receptivity to Tobacco Advertising and Promotions Among Young Adolescents as a Predictor of Established Smoking in Young Adulthood |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume=97 |issue=8 |pages=1489–95 |year=2007 |last1=Gilpin |first1=Elizabeth A |last2=White |first2=Martha M |last3=Messer |first3=Karen |last4=Pierce |first4=John P }}</ref>]]
The period after nicotine advertising restrictions were brought in is characterised by ingenious circumvention of progressively stricter regulations. The industry continued to dispute medical research: denying, for instance, that nicotine was addictive, while deliberately spiking their cigarettes with additional nicotine to make them more addictive.<ref name=NYT_deadly/>
Advertising restrictions typically shift advertising spending to unrestricted media. Banned on television, ads move to print; banned in all conventional media, ads shift to sponsorships; banned as in-store advertising and packaging, advertising shifts to [[shill]] (undisclosed) marketing reps, sponsored online content, [[viral marketing]], and other [[stealth marketing]] techniques.<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|272–280}}
Another method of evading restrictions is to sell less-regulated nicotine products instead of the ones for which advertising is more regulated. For instance, while TV ads of cigarettes are banned in the United States, similar TV ads of e-cigarettes are not.<ref name=exposure_rising>{{Cite web| last = Reuters| title = More U.S. teens seeing e-cigarette ads| website = Business Insider| accessdate = 2018-05-18| url = http://www.businessinsider.com/r-more-us-teens-seeing-e-cigarette-ads-2018-4}}</ref>
The most effective media are usually banned first, meaning advertisers need to spend more money to addict the same number of people.<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|272}} Comprehensive bans can make it impossible to effectively substitute other forms of advertising, leading to actual falls in consumption.<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|272–280}} However, skillful use of allowed media can increase advertising exposure; the exposure of U.S. children to nicotine advertising is increasing as of 2018.<ref name="exposure_rising"/>
[[File:VeteransStadium1986.jpg|thumb|[[Veterans Stadium]], [[Philadelphia]] in 1986; a ban on TV and radio ads meant more reliance on ads at sports venues, which would appear on television]] In the US, sport and event sponsorships and billboards became important in the 1970s and 80s, due to TV and radio advertising bans. Sponsors benefit from placing their advertising at sporting events, naming events after themselves, and recruiting political support from sporting agencies. In the 1980s and 90s, these sponsorships were banned in the US and many other countries. Spending has since shifted to point-of-sale advertising and promotional allowances (where legal), direct mail advertising, and Internet advertising. [[Stealth marketing]] is also becoming more common,<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|100}} partly to offset mistrust of the tobacco industry.<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|Ch.6&7}}
One major Indian company gives annual [[Godfrey Phillips National Bravery Awards|bravery awards in its own name]]; some recipients have rejected or returned them.<ref name="Vivek Returns the Award">{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/04/01/stories/2005040116681100.htm|title=Vivek Oberoi returns award |date=April 1, 2005|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=2013-11-10}}</ref>
{{anchor|Film}} Nicotine use is frequently shown in movies. While academics had long speculated that there was paid [[product placement]], it was not until internal industry documents were released that there was hard evidence of such practices.<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|363–364}} The documents show that in the 1980s and 1990s, cigarettes were shown in return for ≤six-figure (US$) sponsorship deals. More money was paid for a star actor to be shown using nicotine. While this sponsorship is now banned in some countries, it is unclear whether the bans are effective, as such deals are generally not publicized or investigated.<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|401}}
Smokers in movies are generally healthier, more successful, and more racially privileged than actual smokers. Health effects, including coughing and addiction, are shown or mentioned in only a few percent of cases, and are less likely to be mentioned in films targeted at younger viewers.<ref name=media_role/>{{rp|372–374}}
{{anchor|Web}} In the nineties, internet access expanded in many countries; the web is a major medium for nicotine advertising.
Both [[Google]] and [[Microsoft]] have policies that prohibit the promotion of tobacco products on their advertising networks.<ref name=microsoft>[http://advertising.microsoft.com/learning-center/best-practices/ad-content-guidelines/#alcohol_tobacco Advertising.microsoft.com]. Advertising.microsoft.com (28 September 2011).</ref><ref name=google>[http://adwords.google.com/support/aw/bin/static.py?hl=en&page=guidelines.cs&answer=47228&adtype=text Adwords.google.com]. Adwords.google.com.</ref> However, some tobacco retailers are able to circumvent these policies. On Facebook, unpaid content, created and sponsored by tobacco companies, is widely used to advertise nicotine-containing products, with photos of the products, "buy now" buttons and a lack of age restrictions, in contravention of ineffectively enforced Facebook policies.<ref name="cbsnews.com">{{Cite web| last1 = April 5| first1 = Ashley Welch CBS News| last2 = 2018| last3 = Pm| first3 = 5:02| title = Facebook is used to promote tobacco, despite policies against it, study finds| accessdate = 2018-05-18| url = https://www.cbsnews.com/news/facebook-tobacco-products-promotion-sales-study/}}</ref><ref name="Affairs">{{Cite web| last = Affairs| first = By Amy Jeter Hansen Amy Jeter Hansen is a digital media specialist for the medical school's Office of Communication & Public| title = Tobacco products promoted on Facebook despite policies| website = News Center| accessdate = 2018-05-18| url = http://med.stanford.edu/news/all-news/2018/04/tobacco-products-promoted-on-facebook-despite-policies.html}}</ref><ref name="Hansen">{{Cite web| last = Hansen| first = Author Amy Jeter| title = Despite policies, tobacco products marketed on Facebook, Stanford researchers find| website = Scope| accessdate = 2018-05-18| date = 2018-04-05| url = https://scopeblog.stanford.edu/2018/04/05/despite-policies-tobacco-products-marketed-on-facebook/}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=June 2018}}
In 1998, the [[Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement]] was reached between the then four largest [[United States]] [[Tobacco industry|tobacco companies]] Philip Morris (now [[Altria]]), [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company|R. J. Reynolds]], [[Brown & Williamson]] and [[Lorillard Tobacco Company|Lorillard]].
==21st century== {{main|Nicotine marketing}} In 2011, the US [[Food and Drug Administration]] wrote a major review of [[menthol cigarettes]], which are somewhat more addictive and no healthier than regular cigarettes.<ref name=FDA_review/> It was subsequently proposed that they should be banned, partially on grounds that race-specific marketing for a more addictive product is racist.<ref name="auto"/>
==See also== *[[Nicotine marketing]] *[[Health effects of tobacco]]
== Gallery == <gallery mode=nolines style="line-height:130%" widths=150 heights=220> File:Cigarette ad cyclist 1900.jpg|1900 cigarette ad; targeting women is not a new strategy File:Cigar ad yes Im a doctor.jpg|1916 ad showing a fictional doctor endorsing a cigar brand. At the time, it was considered a breach of medical ethics to advertise; doctors who did so would risk losing their license.<ref>http://tobacco.stanford.edu/tobacco_main/images_body.php?token1=fm_img0142.php{{full|date=June 2018}}</ref> File:MuradTurksfull1918Life.jpg|1918 advertisement for "Turkish" cigarettes; [[orientalism]] was in fashion File:Cigar ad harmless good for nerves.jpg|1921 cigar ad claiming that a fictional doctor called this brand "harmless" and "never gets on your nerves" (a term then used for nicotine withdrawal symptoms) File:Small child smokes for charity.jpg|In a 1922 ad, a small child, smoking a cigarette, tells his amused parents not to worry, as he is smoking for a veteran's charity. Children were often used in early cigarette ads, where they helped normalize smoking as part of family living, and gave associations of purity, vibrancy, and life.<ref>http://tobacco.stanford.edu/tobacco_main/images.php?token2=fm_st401.php&token1=fm_img10098.php&theme_file=fm_mt016.php&theme_name=Infants%20&%20Children&subtheme_name=Children%20Smoking{{full|date=June 2018}}</ref> File:Less irritating clears not cures.jpg|alt=Cigarette ad showing an (adult, but child-sized) bellboy holding a pack of cigarettes and pointing at a sign reading: CALL FOR PHILLIP MORRIS / America's <u>''FINEST''</u> Cigarette" On the background above the sign: EMINENT DOCTORS PROVED PHILLIP MORRIS <u>far less irritating to the nose and throat</u>!WHEN SMOKERS CHANGED TO PHILLIP MORRIS, EVERY CASE OF IRRITATION OF NOSE OR THROAT -- DUE TO SMOKING -- EITHER CLEARED UP COMPLETELY OR DEFINITELY IMPROVED! That is from the findings of distinguished doctors in clinical trials of actual smokers -- reported in an authoritative medical journal. We claim no curative powers for Phillip Morris -- but that evidence ''proves them less irritating'' to the nose and throat. <u>In addition</u> -- you will find Phillip Morris finer in taste... more enjoyable End excerpt. Tiny, in lower right corner, a rectangle showing a soldier and the words "FOR VICTORY BUY UNITED STATES WAR SAVINGS BONDS STAMPS". That's all the text apart from that on the package and uniform in the illustration; there's no indication of what studies they are referring to.|"We claim no curative powers for Phillip Morris" say this 1943 ad, in the small text. The FDA was prosecuting brands that did for false advertising. File:Co-ed leaves Campus to fill a Man's job.jpg|''Women in the War'' cigarette ad showing a woman signalling civilian aircraft. The ad associates taking a "man's job" with smoking cigarettes like a man: "Co-ed leaves Campus to fill a <u>Man's</u> job. She's "in the service" -- even to her choice of cigarettes..." File:Fachgeschäft für Tabakwaren.JPG|Tobacco display in a store Munich in 2008. In many countries, cigarettes may not be displayed, but must be kept behind the counter. File:No candy for babies.jpg|Cigarettes in a [[Pokémon]]-branded [[claw crane]] arcade game in 2008 in [[Jaffa]], [[Israel]]. </gallery>

Raghavan]]|Ashok Arora}} |hq_location_city = [[Bangalore|Bengaluru, Karnataka]] |hq_location_country = [[India]] |area_served = Worldwide |key_people = [[Nandan Nilekani]] ([[Chairman]])
[[Salil S. Parekh]] ([[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] & [[Managing Director|MD]]){{cite web|title=Infosys appoints Salil S. Parekh as CEO and Managing Director|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/company/corporate-trends/infosys-appoints-salil-s-parekh-as-ceo-and-managing-director/articleshow/61892804.cms}} |services = [[Information technology|IT]], [[business consulting]] and [[outsourcing]] services |revenue = {{Increase}} {{USD|10.93 billion|link=yes}} (2018) |operating_income = {{Increase}} {{USD|2.66 billion}} (2018) |net_income = {{Increase}} {{USD|2.48 billion}} (2018) |assets = {{Decrease}} {{USD|12.25 billion}} (2018) |equity = {{Decrease}} {{USD|9.96 billion}} (2018) |num_employees = 200,364 (2017) |divisions = {{Unbulleted list|[[Infosys BPM]]|[[EdgeVerve Systems]]|[[Infosys Consulting]]}} |footnotes = {{Cite web|url=https://www.infosys.com/investors/reports-filings/quarterly-results/2017-2018/q4/Documents/IFRS-USD-press-release.pdf|title=Results for the Fourth Quarter and Year ended March 31, 2018|publisher=Infosys Ltd|accessdate=2018-04-13}}{{cite web|url=https://www.infosys.com/investors/financials/Pages/financials-ifrs.aspx|title=Infosys Financial Statements 2017|publisher=Infosys Ltd}} |homepage = {{URL|http://www.infosys.com/}} }} '''Infosys Limited''' (formerly '''Infosys Technologies Limited''') is an Indian [[multinational corporation]] that provides [[business consulting]], [[information technology]] and [[outsourcing]] services. It has its headquarters in [[Bengaluru|Bengaluru, Karnataka, India]].{{cite web |title=Infosys Overview|url=http://www.infosys.com/about/Pages/index.aspx|publisher=Infosys|accessdate=9 June 2014}} Infosys is the second-largest Indian IT company by 2017 revenues and 596th largest public company in the world in terms of revenue.{{cite web | title=Forbes 2017 Global 2000 | url=https://www.forbes.com/global2000/ |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=4 Oct 2017}} On September 28, 2018 its [[market capitalisation]] was $44.32 billion.{{Cite web|url=https://ycharts.com/companies/INFY/market_cap|title=Infosys Market Cap (INFY) - YCharts|date=2018-09-28|website=Ycharts.com|access-date=2018-10-22}} The [[credit rating]] of the company is A- (rating by [[Standard & Poor's]]).{{cite news |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-12-13/news/45162352_1_long-term-corporate-credit-ratings-negative-outlook-abhishek-dangra |title=S&P upgrades TCS, Infosys, Wipro to 'A-' from 'BBB+' |newspaper=The Economic Times |date=13 December 2013 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} ==History== Infosys was established by 7 engineers in [[Pune]], [[India]] with an initial capital of $250 in 1981.{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/business/slide-show/slide-show-1-tech-major-events-in-the-history-of-infosys/20130602.htm#1 |title=Major events in the history of Infosys|publisher=Rediff.com Business |accessdate= 7 October 2017}} It was registered as Infosys Consultants Private Limited on 2 July 1981.{{cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/company-facts/infosys/history/IT#IT |title=Company History of Infosys|publisher=Moneycontrol.com |accessdate= 7 October 2017}} In 1983, it relocated its office to Bengaluru, Karnataka, India. '''Name change''': The company changed its name to ''Infosys Technologies Private Limited'' in April 1992 and to ''Infosys Technologies Limited'' when it became a public limited company in June 1992. It was later renamed to ''Infosys Limited'' in June 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.infosys.com/about/Pages/history.aspx |title=About Infosys |publisher=Infosys |accessdate= 23 September 2013}} '''Share listing''': An initial public offer ([[IPO]]) in February 1993 with an offer price of {{INRConvert|95|year=1993}} per share against book value of {{INRConvert|20|year=1993}} per share. The Infosys IPO was under subscribed but it was [[Bailout|"bailed out"]] by US investment bank [[Morgan Stanley]] which picked up 13% of equity at the offer price.{{cite web |title=Infosys Technologies Bio |publisher=in.com |url=http://www.in.com/infosys-technologies/biography-1818.html |accessdate=7 July 2013}} Its shares were listed in stock exchanges in June 1993 with trading opening at {{INRConvert|145|year=1993}} per share.{{cite web |title=Equity Shares Information |publisher=Infosys|url=http://www.infosys.com/investors/investor-services/Pages/FAQs.aspx |accessdate=7 July 2013}} Its shares were listed on [[NASDAQ]] in 1999 through [[American depositary receipt|ADR]] route. The share price surged to {{INRConvert|8.1|k|year=1999}} by 1999 making it the costliest share on the market at the time. At that time, Infosys was among the 20 biggest companies by market capitalization on the NASDAQ. The ADR listing was shifted from NASDAQ to NYSE Euronext to give its European investors better access to its stock.{{cite web |title=Infosys to shift listing of ADS to NYSE Euronext from Nasdaq |publisher=Infosys|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/infosys-to-shift-listing-of-ads-to-nyse-euronext-from-nasdaq/articleshow/17430643.cms |date=30 Nov 2012 |accessdate=7 Oct 2017}} [[File:Bangalore Infosys .JPG|thumb|right|Infosys, [[Bengaluru]]]] '''Revenue growth''': Its annual revenue touched US$100 million in 1999, US$1 billion in 2004 and US$10 billion in 2017. '''Geographical expansion''': In 2012, Infosys announced a new office in [[Milwaukee]], Wisconsin to service [[Harley-Davidson]], being the 18th international office in the United States.{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21569576-developed-countries-are-beginning-take-back-service-industry-jobs-too-next-big |title=Services: The next big thing |work=The Economist |date=19 January 2013 |accessdate=10 June 2013}}{{cite web |publisher=Infosys.com |title=Infosys to expand its U.S. operations with a new Delivery Center in Wisconsin |url=http://www.infosys.com/newsroom/press-releases/Documents/2012/delivery-center-wisconsin.pdf |accessdate=3 July 2013}} Infosys hired 1,200 United States employees in 2011, and expanded the workforce by an additional 2,000 employees in 2012. In April 2018 Infosys announced expanding in Indianapolis Indiana. The development will include more than 120 acres and is expected to result in 3,000 new jobs — 1,000 more than previously announced.
'''Product and portfolio expansion''': In July 2014, Infosys started a product subsidiary called, [[EdgeVerve Systems]]., focusing on enterprise software products for business operations, customer service, procurement and commerce network domains.{{cite news|title=Edgeverve is born|url=http://wap.business-standard.com/article/companies/infy-s-edgeverve-moves-out-of-parent-s-shadow-114111700414_1.html|accessdate=11 December 2015|publisher=Business Standard|date=November 17, 2014}} In August 2015, the [[Finacle]] Global Banking Solutions assets were officially transferred from Infosys and became part of the product company [[EdgeVerve Systems]] product portfolio.{{cite news|title=Finacle joins Edgeverve|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/we-want-to-be-india-s-top-employer-for-products-michael-reh-115090500596_1.html|accessdate=11 December 2015|publisher=Business Standard|date=September 5, 2015}} ==Products and Services== It provides software development, maintenance and independent validation services to companies in finance, insurance, manufacturing and other domains.{{cite news|title=Infosys realigns organisation structure|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/article/companies/infosys-realings-organisation-structure/39490/|publisher=[[The Financial Express (India)|The Financial Express]]|date=16 Feb 2015}} One of its known products is [[Finacle]] which is a universal banking solution with various modules for retail & corporate banking.{{cite news|title=Core Banking Systems -- Gartner Says The Debate Has Shifted|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomgroenfeldt/2014/11/26/core-banking-systems-gartner-says-the-debate-has-shifted/|publisher=[[Gartner]]|date=26 Nov 2014}} [[File:India Technology.jpg|thumb|Glass building in [[Pune]] campus]] Its key products and services are: * NIA - Next Generation Integrated AI Platform (formerly known as Mana) * [[Infosys Consulting]] - a global management consulting service * Infosys Information Platform (IIP)- Analytics platform * [[EdgeVerve Systems]] which includes [[Finacle]], a global banking platform * [[Panaya]] Cloud Suite * Skava ==Geographical presence== [[File:Infosys Mcity, Building number 5.jpg|thumb|Main block in [[Chennai]] campus]] Infosys had 82 sales and marketing offices and 123 development centres across the world as at March 31, 2018, with major presence in India, United States, China, Australia, Japan, Middle East and Europe.{{citation |url=https://www.infosys.com/investors/shareholder-services/Pages/FAQs.aspx |title=Investor Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) |publisher=Infosys.com |date=31 March 2018 |accessdate=18 July 2018}}{{citation |url=https://www.infosys.com/about/Pages/overview.aspx |title=About Us |publisher=Infosys.com |accessdate=18 July 2018}} In 2017, 61.9%, 22.5% and 3.2% of its revenues were derived from projects in North America, Europe and India, respectively. Remaining 12.4% of revenues were derived from rest of the world.{{cite web |url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/infosys-to-hire-6000-engineers-annually-over-next-2-years/articleshow/60448573.cms |publisher=Economic Times |title= Infosys to hire 6,000 engineers annually over next 2 years |date=2017-09-10 |accessdate=2017-10-20}}{{cite web |url=http://www.infosys.com/investors/reports-filings/Documents/investor-sheet.xls |publisher=Infosys.com |title= Investor Sheet |accessdate=2017-10-04}} ==Acquisitions== {| class="wikitable" |- !
